results.json_description: An expert-level wave and powerful exposed reef break near Majanicho. This shallow, barreling A-frame of exceptional quality works best on a west swell with an east wind. It's known for snapping boards and is truly only for very advanced surfers. Gets crowded very quickly when it's good. Famous for jet-ski assisted tow-in sessions on biggest days. Source: FreshSurf Google Maps integration.

A picturesque and challenging right-hand reef break located in a small, dark sand bay adjacent to the main beach of La Pared. Known for its scenic cliff and large rock tunnel, this spot comes to life when the waves in the main La Pared beach become too large or start to close out. It offers a more sheltered and technical alternative for experienced surfers.

A surfing and windsurfing spot marking the start of Fuerteventura's famous North Shore, located in Corralejo in front of the wind turbines. It is known for its left-hand reef break that produces fast, hollow, and tubular waves. Source: Surfermap Google Maps integration.

An expert-level wave and shallow, barreling A-frame of exceptional quality that works best on a west swell with an east wind. It's known for snapping boards and is truly only for very advanced surfers. Gets crowded very quickly, especially when it's good. Respect the locals; it might be better to watch from the sidelines. Source: FreshSurf Google Maps integration.

google_maps_descriptions.description: Also known as "La Izquierda" (The Left), this is a superb reef wave that works best with a north swell. On a good day, you'll find some great barrel sections. It can get very crowded when it's good. It works best with an east wind and breaks in front of a beautiful beach. The best season is from October to March.

An expert-level wave. This is a shallow, barreling A-frame of exceptional quality that works best on a west swell with an east wind. It's known for snapping boards and is truly only for very advanced surfers. It gets crowded very quickly, especially when it's good. Respect the locals; it might be better to watch from the sidelines. The best season is from October to March.

results.json_description: A regular and reliable reef break known for its hollow and powerful waves over a flat rock bottom. It is considered a regional classic, offering longer rides on good days in a typically uncrowded setting.

A world-class right-hand point break at the southernmost tip of Fuerteventura, famous for its long, perfectly walling waves that are often compared to the legendary point breaks of Australia's Gold Coast. Named after the former Red Cross lifeguard house on the beach, it serves as a primary refuge when the west coast spots are oversized, offering powerful yet ridable waves that wrap around the island.

A stunning, wide beach within the Dunas de Corralejo Natural Park, famous for its fine white sand, crystal-clear water, and dramatic dunes. The spot has a dual character: it features a powerful, hollow, and clean A-frame reef break over a lava shelf for advanced surfers, while the wider beach area offers more forgiving waves. It's a popular hub for surfing, windsurfing, and kitesurfing, with a lively and sometimes competitive atmosphere at the main peak FreshSurf integration: A very powerful beach break with some beautiful sections over a sand-covered reef. It works well when the north gets too big and handles northwest swells best. With a northwest wind, you get offshore conditions that bring out the best in the waves. It's best surfed at high tide and runs well in the summer.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A very powerful beach break with some beautiful sections over a sand-covered reef. It works well when the north gets too big and handles northwest swells best. With a northwest wind, you get offshore conditions that bring out the best in the waves. It's best surfed at high tide and runs well in the summer.

results.json_description: A very long sandy beach with multiple peaks offering both left and right breaks. Powerful beachbreak that can close out on overhead swells but offers makeable barrel sections when banks are good. North end cliffs provide north wind protection FreshSurf integration: A powerful beach break that often closes out when the swell is overhead or the tides are wrong for the sandbanks. The banks improve towards winter and can offer amazing barreling sections. It picks up swell from the north to the west. It's a great spot for intermediates, but also offers excellent whitewater conditions for beginners. This is our preferred beach for teaching, and you can practice here on your own before or after a lesson. El Cotillo works year-round, as long as the swell isn't too big or too small.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A powerful beach break that often closes out when the swell is overhead or the tides are wrong for the sandbanks. The banks improve towards winter and can offer amazing barreling sections. It picks up swell from the north to the west. It's a great spot for intermediates, but also offers excellent whitewater conditions for beginners. This is our preferred beach for teaching, and you can practice here on your own before or after a lesson. El Cotillo works year-round, as long as the swell isn't too big or too small.

A powerful beach break that often closes out when the swell is overhead or the tides are wrong for the sandbanks. The banks improve towards winter and can offer amazing barreling sections. It picks up swell from the north to the west. It's a great spot for intermediates, but also offers excellent whitewater conditions for beginners. This is our preferred beach for teaching, and you can practice here on your own before or after a lesson. El Cotillo works year-round, as long as the swell isn't too big or too small.

results.json_description: A stunning, 250-meter long golden-white sand beach within the Corralejo Dunes Natural Park, famous for its reliable and gentle beach break. It is exceptionally popular with surf schools and is a top destination for beginners and intermediates, especially in summer. The beach is family-friendly, has clear water, and is divided into zones for swimmers and surfers, with active lifeguard supervision FreshSurf integration: A beach break suitable for all levels. It's very popular and well-known among local surf schools. It rarely works in the winter as it needs larger northwest swells. It's most frequently surfed in the summer with northeast wind swells. The best conditions are found between April and September.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A beach break suitable for all levels. It's very popular and well-known among local surf schools. It rarely works in the winter as it needs larger northwest swells. It's most frequently surfed in the summer with northeast wind swells. The best conditions are found between April and September.

results.json_description: A reliable and often crowded left-hand point break located right in Corralejo, offering long, sweet rides next to the harbor wall. This spot is known for its consistent surf but features a gnarly, sharp reef FreshSurf integration: A long, wall-like left-hand wave that offers a super long shoulder. It breaks right at the Corralejo harbor and works best with a west swell and wind. Avoid surfing the left at high tide, as you can get slammed onto the hard lava reef. At high tide, the shorter right-hand wave is the better option. The best season is between November and April.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A long, wall-like left-hand wave that offers a super long shoulder. It breaks right at the Corralejo harbor and works best with a west swell and wind. Avoid surfing the left at high tide, as you can get slammed onto the hard lava reef. At high tide, the shorter right-hand wave is the better option. The best season is between November and April.

results.json_description: The southernmost surf spot on Fuerteventura, located directly in front of the iconic Jandía lighthouse. Famous for its clean, wind-swell-generated left-hand waves that benefit from consistent offshore winds, making it a summer favorite. It offers a versatile wave, from a hollow and steep section right in front of the lighthouse perfect for tubes, to longer, gentler walls further down the beach.

A fearsome and exposed reef break located just outside the harbor of El Cotillo, famous for its powerful, big-wave conditions. It is an expert-only spot where world-class competitions have been held, producing heavy, barreling waves that break over a shallow, rocky bottom.

A gentle and picturesque beach break on the east coast of the Jandía peninsula, below a small tourist settlement. Famous for its long, mellow, left-hand waves generated by consistent northeasterly wind swells, offering rides reminiscent of classic surf films. It's a reliable and safe spot, particularly popular with beginners, longboarders, and families due to its clean conditions and lack of major hazards.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A powerful beach break featuring barreling sections. It picks up swell from the north to the west, with large cliffs providing shelter from northeast winds. The waves here are typically longer than in El Cotillo. Be respectful of the locals—if it's crowded and firing, it might be best to watch for a while. Conditions can be good at any time of year.

results.json_description: A beautiful beach break below a tourist settlement, known for generating gentle, long-running left-hand waves reminiscent of classic surf films. It's a reliable spot powered by wind swells, making it a favorite for beginners and longboarders.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A powerful beach break featuring barreling sections. It picks up swell from the north to the west, with large cliffs providing shelter from northeast winds. The waves here are typically longer than in El Cotillo. Be respectful of the locals—if it's crowded and firing, it might be best to watch for a while. Conditions can be good at any time of year.

results.json_description: A stunning, long sandy beach flanked by massive dunes, famous as the main kitesurfing hub on Fuerteventura but also popular with surfers, wing-foilers, and windsurfers. The bay is protected by reefs on both sides, creating a moderated, user-friendly environment. It offers a beautiful setting with turquoise water and views of Lanzarote and Isla de Lobos.

A dependable and exposed reef break on Fuerteventura's North Shore, offering long, mellow lefts and rights. It's a great spot for intermediates looking to build confidence on a reef, though it can pack power on bigger swells FreshSurf integration: A rather mellow wave that breaks both left and right over a reef. It picks up swell best from the west. The left works from low to mid tide and is at its best with a west wind. The most suitable months are from October to March.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A rather mellow wave that breaks both left and right over a reef. It picks up swell best from the west. The left works from low to mid tide and is at its best with a west wind. The most suitable months are from October to March.

results.json_description: A vast, wild, and breathtakingly beautiful beach on the remote Jandía peninsula, consistently ranked among the most spectacular beaches in the world. This is the longest and most isolated beach on Fuerteventura, backed by majestic mountains and featuring the mysterious Villa Winter. It offers an endless series of shifting sandbanks that provide left and right-hand beach breaks, ensuring an empty peak for those who make the journey. It is a place of raw nature, history, and profound solitude.

A world-class left-hand reef break that mirrors Majanicho, offering long, medium-fast walls with various sections for aerial maneuvers. Features a deep channel that never closes out, handling massive swells up to double mast high.

A shallow, hollow, and powerful reef break located on the inside of the Mejillones bay. It is an expert-only spot known for its fast, barreling waves that break over a sharp volcanic reef, offering a thrilling and technical ride.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A shallow beach break on the inside of Mejiones that breaks both left and right. The wave is also called "Lazy's" because you need very little paddling to catch a tube. It works best with a strong west swell and southwest wind. This spot is known for breaking boards and is only for advanced surfers. The best season is from October to March.

A shallow reef break on the inside of Mejiones that breaks both left and right. The wave is also called "Lazy's" because you need very little paddling to catch a tube. It works best with a strong west swell and southwest wind. This spot is known for breaking boards and is only for advanced surfers. The best season is from October to March.

results.json_description: A popular and exposed right-hand reef break on Fuerteventura's North Shore, famous for its long, fun walls that can provide rides of up to 150 meters. The spot is a consistent performer, attracting a dedicated crowd, especially on weekends FreshSurf integration: Known as the "German's Right," this is a steep right-hand wave that picks up any swell from the north to the west. On a good day, it offers barrel sections. With a large west swell, this is the only spot on the North Shore that still works. On smaller days, a smaller left can be surfed. It works better at low tide. The wave breaks in front of a beautiful sandy beach, which is great for sunbathing. The best season is from October to March.

google_maps_descriptions.description: Known as the "German's Right," this is a steep right-hand wave that picks up any swell from the north to the west. On a good day, it offers barrel sections. With a large west swell, this is the only spot on the North Shore that still works. On smaller days, a smaller left can be surfed. It works better at low tide. The wave breaks in front of a beautiful sandy beach, which is great for sunbathing. The best season is from October to March.

Also known as "La Izquierda" (The Left), this is a superb reef wave that works best with a north swell. On a good day, you'll find some great barrel sections. It can get very crowded when it's good. It works best with an east wind and breaks in front of a beautiful beach. The best season is from October to March.

results.json_description: A powerful beach break within the Corralejo Natural Park, known for its A-frame peaks and barrel sections on a sand-covered reef. It comes alive with the large winter swells, offering a more powerful alternative when the main north shore spots become oversized. The spot is family-friendly with lifeguard services and a relatively relaxed crowd FreshSurf integration: A very powerful beach break with some beautiful tube sections over a sand-covered reef. Currently, there isn't much sand left, making the reef treacherous due to its many holes. It works well when the north is too big and picks up swell best from the northwest. Northwest winds create perfect offshore conditions. It's best surfed at high tide. The most suitable season is from November to April.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A very powerful beach break with some beautiful tube sections over a sand-covered reef. Currently, there isn't much sand left, making the reef treacherous due to its many holes. It works well when the north is too big and picks up swell best from the northwest. Northwest winds create perfect offshore conditions. It's best surfed at high tide. The most suitable season is from November to April.

results.json_description: A beautiful and secluded beach break accessed by a steep staircase, offering a mix of left and right-hand waves. Known for its picturesque, rugged setting and often uncrowded line-ups, it is a great spot for beginners and those seeking a peaceful surf session, though waves can often be close-outs.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A powerful beach break surrounded by beautiful steep cliffs. It's a fantastic spot for beginners and intermediates, especially in the summer on less windy days. It works on swells from the north to the west. The large cliffs offer protection from northeast winds. You'll definitely find longer waves here than in El Cotillo. Conditions can vary, so it's always best to check it on the day.

results.json_description: One of the most renowned and consistent left-hand reef breaks in Fuerteventura, forming part of the famous El Hierro section. This formidable wave breaks over a volcanic reef, offering long, powerful, and fast rides with tubular sections that are highly prized by expert surfers.

google_maps_descriptions.description: Also known as "La Izquierda" (The Left), this is a superb reef wave that works best with a north swell. On a good day, you'll find some great barrel sections. It can get very crowded when it's good. It works best with an east wind and breaks in front of a beautiful beach. The best season is from October to March.

results.json_description: A legendary and expansive beach break on the west coast, situated at the narrowest part of the island. Known locally as 'El Viejo Rey,' it is one of the most famous and wave-safe spots in southern Fuerteventura, virtually guaranteed to have surfable waves year-round. It's a foundational spot where many surfers catch their first white water waves and a reliable canvas for all levels, thanks to its long, shifting sandbanks.

A wild, remote beach located in the scenic and untamed Jandía Natural Park, known for its dramatic landscape of cliffs meeting dark blue water. This secluded spot offers a powerful beach break in a rugged, undeveloped setting for experienced surfers seeking to escape the crowds.

A wild, expansive, and remote sandy beach on Fuerteventura's west coast, famous for its powerful surf and rugged Atlantic charm. It's a reliable spot that picks up swell when other parts of the island are flat, offering a chance to escape the crowds.

google_maps_descriptions.description: When the North Shore is flat, you'll likely find waves here. This beach break picks up swell from the north to the west. It's an easy-to-surf wave suitable for all levels and works best with an east wind. The best season is from September to October.

results.json_description: A fun and accessible breakwater wave that offers left-hand rides along a harbor wall. It's a wind-protected spot, making it a good option on bigger north shore days and a perfect wave for longboarders.

An exposed and consistent reef break located in the remote south of Fuerteventura, within the Jandía peninsula. This right-hand point offers a reliable wave in a less crowded setting, making it a spot for surfers seeking to escape the crowds.

A legendary and exposed reef break off the coast of Fuerteventura, offering one of the longest and most mechanical right-hand waves in the entire Atlantic region. Accessible only by boat, this spot transforms into a reeling, world-class point break on large NW swells, creating rides of several hundred meters in a dramatic lunar landscape.

A hidden gem on the famous Grandes Playas, located directly in front of the Riu hotels. This spot is unique for its completely soft, sandy bottom, making it exceptionally safe and forgiving. It's a perfect, mellow beach break for beginners and intermediates, but surfing is only permitted in the evening after the lifeguards finish their duty.

A picturesque, tranquil fishing village with a consistent reef break offering long, predictable right-handers perfect for cutbacks and intermediate practice. The spot features multiple breaks including a main peak and inside sections.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A famous A-frame that starts working perfectly when the other spots on the North Shore are too big. It remains surfable even with strong onshore wind. To avoid a tricky walk over the reef, enter the water from the corner of the small beach. The best season is from November to April.

A mellow right-hander that starts working when the main spots on the North Shore are too big. It's still surfable with onshore wind. To avoid a tricky walk over the reef, enter the water from the corner of the small beach. It's perfect for intermediates or longboarders. The best season is from November to April.

An easy-to-surf right-hand wave that works best with a north swell. When the outer reef gets too big, the inner reef starts to work. The wave offers long rides and a solid shoulder, great for practicing cutbacks. It's a fantastic wave for intermediates and cruisers, working best with an east wind at low tide. During a "Calima" (strong east wind), you'll find many windsurfers here. The paddle-out is long, so you'll need some power. It has also become a famous SUP spot.

results.json_description: Famous big-wave spot known for powerful waves over shallow reef. Features the unique 'Popcorn Beach' with white coral fragments. When pumping, you might witness tow-in surfing. A serious board-snapper spot for experts only.

A little-known but high-quality reef break located just north of Puerto del Rosario. This spot is powerful and exposed, capable of producing excellent waves that are occasionally featured in local surfing competitions. It remains a more local and uncrowded alternative to the island's famous north shore spots.

A long, sandy beach break located in the capital city of Puerto del Rosario on the east coast. Known for its gentle, sloppy, and less powerful waves, it is a prime learning ground and a reliable fallback spot when the west coast is too strong. It's very popular with surf schools and ideal for beginners making their first attempts on unbroken green waves, thanks to its consistent wind swells and evenly sloping sandy bottom FreshSurf integration: Playa Blanca is a large sandy beach located between the airport and Puerto del Rosario. It's most commonly surfed in the summer because it requires strong northeast wind swells. It's a great beginner spot, with relatively mellow and sometimes a bit messy waves. Works all year round.

google_maps_descriptions.description: Playa Blanca is a large sandy beach located between the airport and Puerto del Rosario. It's most commonly surfed in the summer because it requires strong northeast wind swells. It's a great beginner spot, with relatively mellow and sometimes a bit messy waves. Works all year round.

results.json_description: A large, powerful bay located just north of the island's capital, Puerto del Rosario. This spot features an A-frame reef break over a rocky bottom known for its stone slabs ('lajas'). It comes alive with northeastern wind swells, offering a mix of left and right-hand waves. It's a multi-purpose spot popular with surfers, wing-foilers, windsurfers, and kitesurfers, especially in the morning and evening before the trade winds pick up FreshSurf integration: A large bay located just north of the island's capital. It offers left and right waves that break over a reef. This spot is often surfed in the summer, as the wave is formed by northeast wind swells, which can produce head-high sets. It's best surfed in the morning and evening. During the day, wind and kite surfers often take over when the trade winds pick up. It works best between April and September.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A large bay located just north of the island's capital. It offers left and right waves that break over a reef. This spot is often surfed in the summer, as the wave is formed by northeast wind swells, which can produce head-high sets. It's best surfed in the morning and evening. During the day, wind and kite surfers often take over when the trade winds pick up. It works best between April and September.

results.json_description: A fun and mellow reef break perfect for beginners and improvers. Known for its mushy, sometimes disordered waves that are great for long white water rides. It's a swell magnet that consistently picks up waves, though it can often be messy. Importantly, it is a primary windsurfing spot, so surfers need to be mindful of sharing the water FreshSurf integration: A brilliant spot for beginners with calmer, somewhat disorganized waves. It's perfect for your first long whitewater rides and for catching smaller, reforming green waves further out. This spot is atypical for the North Shore as the waves don't break in a perfectly orderly fashion. You can almost always find a wave here, big or small. Sometimes it's great for longboarders when it's clean and small. Works all year round.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A brilliant spot for beginners with calmer, somewhat disorganized waves. It's perfect for your first long whitewater rides and for catching smaller, reforming green waves further out. This spot is atypical for the North Shore as the waves don't break in a perfectly orderly fashion. You can almost always find a wave here, big or small. Sometimes it's great for longboarders when it's clean and small. Works all year round.

results.json_description: A secluded and exposed reef break located in the scenic south of Fuerteventura near Punta de Jandía. Known for its powerful, tubular waves breaking over a rocky, volcanic seabed, this spot offers a solitary surfing experience amid dramatic natural beauty.

A prominent and reliable reef break situated between the island of Lobos and Corralejo. When the North Shore gets big, this spot comes to life with a long, shoulder-breaking right-hand wave on the outside, while the inside offers faster, smaller lefts and rights. It has become a famous spot for intermediates, longboarders, and SUP riders.

google_maps_descriptions.description: When the North Shore is too big, a wave forms between Corralejo and Lobos Island. The outer reef breaks as a large right-hander with long rides. On the inside, a smaller wave breaks both left and right. The outside is a well-known SUP spot. This wave is well-suited for intermediates and longboarders. Enter the water 'around the corner' to avoid a long walk over sharp lava rock. It works best between November and March.

results.json_description: A sheltered left-hand point break that reforms large swells into a wave that peels predictably into the bay. It's a go-to spot when conditions are too big, messy, or windy elsewhere on the North Shore, offering several sections to play with.

google_maps_descriptions.description: A sheltered surf spot, ideal when it's too big, messy, or windy everywhere else. It can even handle strong onshore winds. Large swells reform over a shallow take-off zone, creating a beautiful left with several smaller sections. Be aware of the strong current; constant paddling is essential.

results.json_description: A remote and historically significant bay on the wild west coast, famed as the final resting place of the SS American Star shipwreck. Unlike other exposed west coast spots, its unique geography provides lighter and often offshore wind conditions. It features a versatile beach break with distinct left and right-hand peaks, a relatively safe channel for paddling out, and a friendly, sheltered vibe that attracts everyone from beginners in the white water to advanced surfers on the main peaks.

A heavy and exposed reef break on the infamous North Shore, aptly named for its gnarly and suicidal right-hand wave that breaks over a sharp lava reef. The main break features two very fast, hollow, and powerful sections, with the first being notoriously difficult to make. It is a spot for experts with local knowledge only, where mastering the wave can offer the barrel of a lifetime.

A sheltered and versatile bay in the heart of Corralejo, famous as a primary hub for wing foiling and windsurfing. On smaller days, it also offers a gentle, accessible wave in the middle of the bay, making it a popular spot for beginner surfers thanks to its easy access from town and protection from strong wind and currents.
